block.p: LEAD:
International

The political impasse in Lithuania appeared to be moving closer to compromise after the intervention of the French and German leaders and a wave of backstage contacts between Moscow and the rebellious republic, officials in Vilnius said.
Page 1
President Bush's Lithuanian policy was attacked by nine Republican Senators, the first serious break in Congressional support for the Administration's handling of the Baltic situation.
LEAD:
International

The political impasse in Lithuania appeared to be moving closer to compromise after the intervention of the French and German leaders and a wave of backstage contacts between Moscow and the rebellious republic, officials in Vilnius said.
Page 1
President Bush's Lithuanian policy was attacked by nine Republican Senators, the first serious break in Congressional support for the Administration's handling of the Baltic situation.
International

The political impasse in Lithuania appeared to be moving closer to compromise after the intervention of the French and German leaders and a wave of backstage contacts between Moscow and the rebellious republic, officials in Vilnius said.
Page 1
President Bush's Lithuanian policy was attacked by nine Republican Senators, the first serious break in Congressional support for the Administration's handling of the Baltic situation.
The Chernobyl nuclear disaster had much greater medical, environmental and political consequences than the Kremlin ever discussed, the Soviet Union now acknowledges.
News analysis: The member nations of the European Community are still far from agreement over how much sovereignty they are willing to surrender to achieve political union.
Prague journal: The owner-manager of the sole private restaurant in the capital of Czechoslovakia, a city of 1.2 million, is proud of having opened it a year ago, under the old Government.
Bucharest is split into rival camps in election
The toll of AIDS in Zambia has been very high. As in the rest of Africa, the disease is spread primarily by heterosexual intercourse and has hit men and women almost equally.

Acting Prime Minister Shamir of Israel accepted the official mandate to form a Likud government, and he quickly dismissed the Labor Party's suggestion that a new short-term ''national unity'' government be formed.

The contra military commander has taken a tough new line and said his rebel army would keep its guns until the Nicaraguan Government dismantled the entire ''repressive structure'' set up by the Sandinistas.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is considering major changes in the unpopular new Government tax, the British press reported. The poll tax went into effect in England and Wales on April 1 and in Scotland a year earlier.

Italians can send money overseas following the removal of the last of Italy's controls on capital movements. The move may shrink the captive pool of savings the Government has tapped to finance its huge budget deficits.
National

A genetically engineered drug used in dairy cows will be temporarily barred in Wisconsin under legislation approved by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. The action could spell enormous trouble for the fledgling agricultural biotechnology industry.

An Illinois law barring fetal research was struck down by a Federal district judge in Chicago. She said it was so broad that it forbade women to get advanced treatments for infertility and genetic screening of the fetus.
Philadelphia's transit system paid out more for personal injury claims than any system in the nation last year. The system is plagued by fraudulent claims, officials say.
The nation's economy grew at a moderate 2.1 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year, and inflation took its biggest quarterly jump since 1981, the Commerce Department reported.
U.S. drops Japan from target list

Loggers and sawmill workers in the Pacific Northwest are demanding compensation from the Federal Government for the 10,000 jobs that are expected to be lost in order to save some of the nation's oldest trees and the owls that live among them.
California farmer charged with enslaving Mexican workers
Census forms should be returned as soon as possible, President Bush said. He wants to speed the lagging count, which Republicans hope will help them gain seats in Congress.
Spending bill's progress slowed by unrelated issues

The Hubble Space Telescope opened its huge aluminum eyelid and let in the first light from the heavens. No pictures of astronomical objects will be taken until next week, and the telescope will not begin full-time observations for several months.
Guns and lodging await prairie dogs and tourists
Lava's threat may overcome town

Violence aimed primarily at blacks who moved to white neighborhoods accounted for about half of the nation's racial hate crimes last year, a survey conducted by a group that monitors such activity shows.
Killer of four is executed in South Carolina
Judge rules patient can fulfill her wish to die
Regional

A woman's right to have an abortion in Connecticut would be assured even if the Supreme Court strikes down the Roe v. Wade decision that has dictated national abortion law since 1973 under a bill overwhelmingly approved by the Connecticut Senate.

Both sides in the abortion tussle agree that gathering the support of politicians and the public remains central to the debate. As a result, the opposing forces are seeking to impress with the number of supporters at a rally in Washington, D.C.

Covenant House's self-examination, which followed the resignation of its founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, has been driven both by sharp drops in fund raising and by criticism of some of the charity's programs.

The St. Regis Indian Reservation in upstate New York continues to be troubled by feuding between heavily armed rival Mohawk factions, which are fighting over the issue of allowing casino gambling. Governor Cuomo has been asked to intervene.

Grand Central Terminal would undergo sweeping changes to restore its majestic interior and transform the terminal into a major center for retail, civic and cultural activities under a plan introduced by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

The city's highways are a mess. The New York City Department of Transportation planted 500 roadside trees yesterday, in part to mark Arbor Day and in part to signal its concern about the state of the highways.
Perrier came back to New York City, but the reintroduction was not as trouble free as the company's $25 million campaign had planned.
Trenton panel suggests ouster of school aide
Three students from St. John's are indicted
Ex-mental patient says he saw Fama fire four times
Number of holding cells in Manhattan to double
Business Digest
Arts/Entertainment
Brooklyn Museum expansion starts Monday
Papp receives pledges
Carol Burnett returns to TV
Theater: ''Sugar Hill''
''Rodents and Radios''
Film: ''Space Invaders''
''Wild Orchid''
Music: Shostakovich ''Leningrad'' by Philharmonic
Book: Writing from Poland

Baseball: Mets top Astros
Yanks beat Angels
Basketball: Knicks manage to self-destruct
Bulls defeat Bucks
Boxing: Hearns seeks a brighter spotlight
Column: Berkow on Larry Bird
Hockey: Capitals eliminate Rangers
Bruins win series
Sports People
Track and Field: Villanova women set mark in relay
Consumer's World
Health threat warning over insect repellents
Covering up in the season for taking it off
Coping with vacation-picture blues
Obituaries
Charlotte Boschan, an economist
Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed
Editorials
The best of a bad trade law
What crime victims need
Setting a fair course
Two Bronx elections
Letters
Flora Lewis: Baghdad rages on
Russell Baker: The Beerlin wall
Martin Garbus: Thornburgh's morality brigade
Stansfield Turner and Thomas Davies: Shipping plutonium
Phyllis A. Hayes: Paris is for lovers, not joggers
